results.title: Feelings: don't stay mad
results.creator_credit: Abram Murray and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Discusses the fact that people should not let feelings grow until they are overwhelmed by them. Suggests that anger can be talked out or acted out in positive ways. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Feeling yes, feeling no. Parts 1, 2 and 3
results.creator_credit: Moira Simpson, Jennifer Torrance, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Feeling yes, feeling no Parts 1, 2 and 3 are part of a sexual assault prevention program for young children. The purpose of this video is to give children the skills necessary to protect themselves from sexual assault - from strangers, from family members, from other trusted people. Part 1 teaches children basic skills that build self-worth, self-confidence and good judgement. Part 2 reinforces the understanding of “Yes” feelings and “No” feelings and introduces skills to keep children assess potentially dangerous situations involving strangers. Part 3, introduces the issue of sexual assault by a trusted adult. Cast includes: Barbara Duncan, Fran Gebhard and Brian Torpe. (Awards: Montreal; Oakland; Mauriac)

results.title: Feeding and clothing China's millions
results.creator_credit: Andy Thomson, Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This exotic film provides a detailed picture of a very different culture, a cooperative and conserver society of the North China plain. Life here revolves around agriculture—wheat, rice and cotton crops—and almost everyone is involved in their intense cultivation. A cotton factory in an industrial city reveals another link in China’s massive, coordinated efforts to ensure its people adequate food, clothing, shelter and jobs.

results.title: Fear and Fantasy (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “All in the Mind Series”.
A psychological study of anxiety and prejudice. Highlights how anxiety is the root source of many prejudices and how group training procedures can provide personal insight into problems.

results.title: Love Me Do (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “All in the Mind Series”.
Examines the social psychology of relationships, considers how stable social relationships are vital to human beings and shows how social abilities greatly influence an individual’s health and happiness.

results.title: Feed them to the cannibals!
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cunningham Reid, Baobab Productions and Dangerous to Know
results.brief_description: In 1972 a small number of lesbians and gay men held the first Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras in Sydney, a then militant solidarity march for gay rights. Over the last two decades the Sydney Gay Mardi Gras has become one of the biggest festivals around the world, attracting hundreds of thousands of international and domestic tourists every year. The film explores the history of the Sydney lesbian and gay community, a community organised around relationships of love, solidarity and pleasure and which is challenging the traditional ways society has understood family, love and commitment. Many of the activists interviewed discuss the changes in gay and lesbian politics over the last twenty years and the changes in the lived experiences of non-heterosexuality.

results.title: Faust
results.creator_credit: Friedrich W. Murnau, Erich Pommer and UFA
results.brief_description: Classic silent German cinema from the talented F.W.Murnau, 1926. “The portals of darkness are open and the shadows of the dead hunt over the earth..” opens the film with the prevailing theme of good versus evil as the devil Mephisto does a deal with alchemist Faust for his soul and potentially for dominion over the Earth - promising he will stop the plague that is rife throughout Faust’s village. Faust reneges on the arrangement choosing love - much to the delight of Archangel St. Michael. Based on the original story by Goethe. Great cinematography and effects give the film a dark foreboding and general creepiness that add to the dramatic impact of the work. This edition features orchestral soundtrack by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.

results.title: Father, son and holy war. Parts 1 and 2
results.brief_description: Controversial Indian filmmaker Anand Patwardhan (War and peace = Jang aur aman) is confronting and courageous in tackling head on in this two-part documentary, the religious and political violence which currently exists in India today between the Hindi majority and the Islamic minority. More importantly however, is the understanding and historical background of India’s culture and belief system which is provided through personal stories and interviews from a broad spectrum of societal, political and religious Hindus and Muslims. Anand examines the crisis of male identity among the Hindus and their obsession with male strength, power and control over their women and over Muslims. He also highlights the rise of civil rights and women’s resistance movements and the call for equality and peace between the two religions. Anand walks the fine line in his attempt to maintain balance but the overriding issue is that of women, whether Hindu or Muslim, and their appalling treatment by extremists from both sides. Part 1. Trial by fire: Begins with a Hindu perspective of the Bombay riots in 1993 where Hindus set fire to Muslim shops and then follows with a historical look into how and why matriarchal India turned into the patriarchal India of today with its roots of continuing religious violence. Part 2. Hero pharmacy: Explores manhood, sexuality and physicality and their relationship to conflict and violence, juxtaposed with the awareness by women of their own place in society and a calling for unity, equality and humanity in religion. Also shows the 1993 Bombay riots from a Muslim perspective. Includes some b&w footage. In English and Hindi with English subtitles.
